primarysource.reporterstreet: 1330 Contra Costa Avenue Apartment L203 13728 Sand Pablo Avenue Unit 1021

reaction.primarysourcereaction: failure to recognize and treat secondary adrenal insufficiency
using 12 mg cartridge in 6 mg pen
can not see without her glasses

summary.narrativeincludeclinical:
This spontaneous case, reported by a consumer with additional information received from a physician and the consumer, with additional information provided by the physician, concerns a 76 year old African-American female patient.
Medical history included diabetes mellitus, pituitary tumor treated with heavy particle pituitary irradiation, chest pain, dorsolumbar disc disease, lumbar disc surgery, hypertension, hypercholesterolemia, hyperprolactinemia, diplopia, right lid surgery, myocardial infarction, adrenal insufficiency, gastroenteritis, cervical disc disease, and she had multiple unspecified medical problems. Her tumor was destroyed but many years she developed panhypopituitarism. The patient was a current smoker. Concomitant medications included 19 different unreported prescriptions, estrogen, levothyroxine sodium, and hydrocortisone.
The patient received somatropin (Humatrope) 0.20 mg daily, subcutaneously via concomitant Humatropen for treatment of growth hormone deficiency beginning on an unknown date. Her somatropin dose was increased to 0.30mg on unknown date and then to 0.70mg in Apr-2010. The patient had been receiving somatropin treatment approximately just under one year when she was diagnosed as anemic, date unknown. The patient's right shoulder was also out of socket and she had numbness in her right hand which had been going on for a few weeks, dates unknown. The patient was able to use it but it was taking her longer. The patient then suffered from a stomach virus (gastroenteritis) and secondary dehydration, considered serious by the reporter for hospitalization approximately on 16Sep2011. She also experienced vomiting and had diarrhea. The patient was released from hospital three days later on 18Sep2011 without receiving adrenal steroids during her entire hospitalization. The day after she was discharged, she appeared at physician's office. She was weak and hypertensive. Physician stated that during the previous hospitalization they failed to recognize and treat secondary adrenal insufficiency. Physician gave her parenteral adrenal hormone replacement (hydrocortisone sodium succinate) and hydrated with oral fluids. Blood pressure came up to normal and the patient was dramatically improved. It was also reported the patient had been using 12mg somatropin cartridges in a 6mg Humatropen for the length of time of receiving treatment (over a year). The patient was advised not to use that device and that the appropriate device would be delivered. In addition, patient also experienced shoulder pain and vision problems as she could not see without her glasses. It was also reported that patient had previous hospital admissions in the past several years but no reasons were provided. Sometime in Sep-2012 she was hospitalized for three days due to dehydration and an infection in her left cardiac artery. She was given unspecified intravenous fluids and medication. As of 19Nov2012 she continued to use a 6 mg humatropen with a 12 mg somatropin cartridge and was in an assisted living facility that did not require 24 hour nursing. Patient had recovered from gastroenteritis, adrenal insufficiency, the infection in her cardiac artery, and secondary dehydration but outcome of the remaining events were not reported. Somatropin was ongoing.
In the opinion of reporting physician the events were not related to somatropin treatment however no sufficient rationale were provided.
Update 20-Oct-2011: Additional information received from the initial reporter on 11-Oct-2011: Added non-serious events of shoulder pain and vision impairment and also added patient date of birth. Fields and narrative were updated.
Update 24-Feb-2012: Additional information received from a physician on 15-Feb-2012. Added the physician as a reporter. Added serious events of adrenal insufficiency, dehydration and hospitalization, updated causality and deleted non-serious events of vomiting and diarrhea. Also updated patient demographics, added medical history and concomitant medications. Fields and narrative were updated.
Edit 28Feb2012: Corrected patient age in narrative and on patient tab.
Update 28-Nov-2012: Additional information was received via a consumer on 19-Nov-2012. Added: patient demographic information; dose tab; lot number; serious event of cardiac infection and deydration. Updated narrative accordingly.
Update 21Jan2013: Additional information was received from the physician on 15Jan2013: Changed outcome of infection in her cardiac artery to recovered from unknown, updated history to include multiple unspecified medical conditions, added treatment medications (intravenous fluids and hydrocortisone sodium succinate), removed serious event of hospitalization, changed reported causality of dehydration and infection of cardiac artery from not reported to no and as determined causality from not reported to yes for same events, updated the relatedness statement, updated medical history, and updated the narrative.
